awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF:  Testing the boundaries of Burgess Shale-Type preservation with literature meta-analysis, decay experimentation, and fossil investigation
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Evan Anderson has been granted an EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to carry out research and education plans at the University of Missouri. The research plan will focus on studying the Burgess Shale-type (BST) mode of soft-bodied preservation from multiple approaches to better understand the scope and operational mechanisms of this paleontologically important preservation mode. Soft-bodied fossils can provide ecological and evolutionary information available nowhere else in the fossil record. The education activities will include developing teaching modules for K12 and undergraduate students. The materials for these modules will include common softbodied materials (i.e. graptolites and plant debris), 3-D printed and traditional print-outs of exceptional soft-bodied materials, and materials collected for this study.
 
This investigation will have three components. First, a literature meta-analysis will study and expand a compendium of exceptional soft-bodied fossil deposits (or lagerstätten) to isolate BST and BST-like deposits throughout earth history. Comparing these deposits will both highlight shared characteristics and explore the variation within the BST mode of fossilization. Second, decay experiments will test two models of BST preservation for their effectiveness in slowing soft-bodied degradation. One experiment will test the hypothesis that complex bioturbation prevents BST preservation by oxygenating sediments and enhancing decay by simulating different kinds of burrows penetrating the sediment in which a decay organism is buried. The second experiment will test the hypothesis that elevated calcium and alkalinity levels allows for the development of calcite permeability seals in BST deposits, protecting buried organisms from degradation. Finally, a fossil-based investigation will compare the burial context and fossil preservation of freshly collected material from the BST-like Winneshiek and Waukesha lagerstätten to traditional open marine BST deposits from the Cambrian House Range of Utah. Although the BST-like deposits come from post-Cambrian deposits with restricted water circulation, if the fossil preservational mineralogies and qualities are similar between the BST-like and BST deposits, then their burial environment conditions should be comparable (i.e. calcite seals).

por.por_cntn:
Soft-bodied fossils, which preserve features that are not bones or shells, are relatively uncommon but can provide very important information on the anatomy and biological affinity (that is, the taxonomy) of the ancient relatives of modern organisms and completely extinct organisms. A famous and important deposit of soft-bodied fossils is the Burgess Shale Formation, which records the diversity of animal and algae life after the Cambrian Explosion; It lends it's name to the Burgess Shale-type of soft-bodied fossil deposits, where fossils are preserved as compressed, carbon films with coats of clay, some pyrite (or fools gold), and sometimes calcium phosphate can preserve intestinal tracts.  Importantly, the Burgess Shale-type occurs in open marine sediments from ancient oceans.

This project sought to explore the limits of the Burgess Shale-type of fossil preservation: how it is distributed through time (the first component), to test hypotheses on how organisms were fossilized in the preservation type (the second component), and to explore whether deposits from later in the fossil record, in different depositional settings, could be considered "extensions" of the type (the third component).

To pursue the first component, an investigation of a thoroughly compiled and detailed list of soft-bodied fossil deposits through the last 630 million years has shown that the occurrence of "Burgess Shale-type" fossil deposits through time depends on how specifically one defines the type.  If defined as deposits with fossil preserved as carbonaceous films – probably the single most important component – occurrences wax and wane with time, following general trends in soft-bodied fossil abundance.  If the conditions are defined narrowly (i.e. carbon films with clay, pyrite, phosphate, and marine rocks, or different combinations of these), their incidence drops off sharply after the Cambrian Period ends about 485 million years ago (mya). 

To pursue the second component, a series of modern experiments were performed where euthanized shrimp were buried in jars with kaolinite (a kind of clay which is a component of the very fine-grained clays that preserve actual Burgess Shale-type fossils), which were then filled with water resembling the modern ocean, the more calcium-rich oceans typical of the Cambrian period, or salt water with twice the amount of calcium as the "Cambrian" ocean water.  These treatments were done to test the hypothesis that the formation of calcite seals in burying sediments entombed organisms that would become Burgess Shale-type fossils, starving the microbes that would normally degrade dead organisms of nutrients and oxygen.

Measurements of our experiment replicates using chemical microprobes showed that decay was most intense after one week, and slowed afterward. Still, even after seven weeks some material of the shrimp could be recovered, usually just the outer shell. We were never able to find a coherent calcite seal, but the fine grained sediment served as a good barrier on it's own: chemical conditions were usually very different in the sediment compared to the overlying water column.  Additionally, genetic assays of the microbes decaying the buried shrimp showed strong differences between those buried in ocean water, and those in Cambrian-like calcium-rich ocean waters.

For the third component, we looked at two later deposits dominated by arthropods (animals like crustaceans and scorpions), like the Burgess Shale-type deposits often are: The Winneshiek from the Ordovician Period (about 485–444 mya) of Iowa, and the Waukesha from the Silurian Period (about 444–419 mya) of Wisconsin. In both cases, the preservation pathways of the fossils were somewhat different than Burgess Shale-type fossils: though usually made of carbon sheets, little Ceratiocaris crustaceans from the Winneshiek could also be preserved with lots of calcium phosphate; the thick sea scorpion cuticle of the Winneshiek was carbon enriched with sulfur.  At the Waukesha, most fossils were carbon sheets or films, with substantial deposits of sulfate-rich calcium phosphate called francolite. Francolite replicated cuticle, muscle, and bristles, but only sometimes preserved intestinal tracts. We also took the opportunity to officially describe some of the fossils at the Waukesha, particularly the unusual arthropods.

The project also presented opportunities to deliver broader impacts in teaching others and promoting interest in paleontology and the sciences generally.  Lesson plans and materials for an undergraduate-level lab on soft-bodied fossil preservation were created and tested, and these plans were modified into an activity practiced with a group of elementary-aged students on the department's Geology Club Youth Night.  A graduate-level course was also designed and implemented called Taxonomy and Phylogeny, which taught students how, theoretically and practically, organisms are scientifically described and related to one another through manual and computer analysis.

In sum, this project has offered intriguing insight on the Burgess Shale-type of soft-bodied fossilization, it's distribution through time, how it may, or may not have occurred in the Cambrian, and how we may relate, both taxonomically and from a preservation standpoint, the fossils of Burgess Shale-type deposits to those from the Ordovician, Silurian, and later.

Images (1 of )
  • A Ceratiocaris fossil from the Winneshiek Formation, about 8 mm long. Note the two, carbon-rich eyes on the anterior end. The long tail end extends from the carapace on the left.
    Evan Anderson, PI
    Public Domain
    Evan P Anderson
    WL22-3, Winneshiek Ceratiocaris
  • An ostracod from the Waukesha soft-bodied fossil deposit, photographed under low angle light. Its carapace and some internal features (likely leg bristles) have been preserved with calcium phosphate. When removed, diffuse carbon underlies the phosphate. About 8 mm long
    Evan Anderson, PI
    Public Domain
    Evan P Anderson
    UWGM4777 Waukesha Ostracod
  • An underlit portion of a sea scorpion (Pentecopterus decorahensis) from the Winneshiek Formation, showing the serrated boundary between leg segments. The ruddy brown cuticle is made of carbon, but has a sulfur component, too. Main segment about 2 cm wide
    Evan Anderson, PI
    Public Domain
    Evan P Anderson
    Winneshiek sea scorpion cuticle
  • A close-up of individual segments and legs of an individual of Parioscorpio venator from the Waukesha soft-bodied fossil deposit, showing preservation in both calcium phosphate and carbon sheets. Each segment is about 1 mm long.
    Evan Anderson, PI
    Public Domain
    Evan P Anderson
    UWGM 2857a Parioscorpio venator trunk
  • Sampled at 7 weeks with a microprobe, this shrimp-bearing burial experiment replicate shows sulfide deposits in the sediment, and a microbial veil that grew on the water surface; the probe dragged the veil down with it into the water column.
    Evan Anderson, PI
    Public Domain
    Evan P Anderson
    Oxic Instant Ocean Microprobe Replicate 1
  • A shrimp-bearing burial experiment replicate for microbial assay, sampled at 1 week. Decay evidence was typically most intense at the first week; notice evidence of putrefaction on the sediment surface and in the cloudy water column.
    Evan Anderson, PI
